## Repository files navigation

- <a href="#" class="prc-components-UnderlineItem-7fP-n" aria-current="page"><span data-component="icon"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-book" /></span><span data-component="text" data-content="README">README</span></a>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-list-unordered" />

</div>

<div class="Box-sc-62in7e-0 js-snippet-clipboard-copy-unpositioned DirectoryRichtextContent-module__SharedMarkdownContent__aH1R11y" hpc="true">

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

# 🚲 fixi.js - *it ain't much...*

<a href="#-fixijs---it-aint-much" id="user-content--fixijs---it-aint-much" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: 🚲 fixi.js - it ain&#39;t much..."><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

<a href="https://swag.htmx.org/products/fixi-js-tee" rel="nofollow">fixi.js</a> is an experimental, minimalist implementation of <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3648188.3675127" rel="nofollow">generalized hypermedia controls</a>

The fixi [api](#api) consists of six [HTML attributes](#attributes), nine [events](#events) & two [properties](#properties)

Here is an example:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/content&quot; &lt;!-- URL to issue request to --&gt;
        fx-method=&quot;get&quot;      &lt;!-- HTTP Method to use --&gt;
        fx-trigger=&quot;click&quot;   &lt;!-- Event that triggers the request --&gt;
        fx-target=&quot;#output&quot;  &lt;!-- Element to swap --&gt;
        fx-swap=&quot;innerHTML&quot;&gt; &lt;!-- How to swap --&gt;
    Get Content
&lt;/button&gt;
&lt;output id=&quot;output&quot;&gt;&lt;/output&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/content" <!-- URL to issue request to -->
            fx-method="get"      <!-- HTTP Method to use -->
            fx-trigger="click"   <!-- Event that triggers the request -->
            fx-target="#output"  <!-- Element to swap -->
            fx-swap="innerHTML"> <!-- How to swap -->
        Get Content
    </button>
    <output id="output"></output>

</div>

When this fixi-powered `button` is clicked it will issue an HTTP `GET` request to the `/content` <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/WD-html40-970917/htmlweb.html#h-5.1.2" rel="nofollow">relative URL</a> and swap the HTML content of the response inside the `output` tag below it.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## Minimalism

<a href="#minimalism" id="user-content-minimalism" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Minimalism"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Philosophically, fixi is <a href="https://scheme.org/" rel="nofollow">scheme</a> to <a href="https://htmx.org" rel="nofollow">htmx</a>'s <a href="https://lisp-lang.org/" rel="nofollow">common lisp</a>: it is designed to be as <a href="https://ia601608.us.archive.org/8/items/pdfy-PeRDID4QHBNfcH7s/LeanSoftware_text.pdf" rel="nofollow">lean as possible</a> while still being useful for real world projects.

As such, it doesn't have many of the features found in htmx, including:

- <a href="https://htmx.org/attributes/hx-sync/" rel="nofollow">request queueing &amp; synchronization</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#extended-css-selectors" rel="nofollow">extended selector support</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#special-events" rel="nofollow">extended event support</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#inheritance" rel="nofollow">attribute inheritance</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#indicators" rel="nofollow">request indicators</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#css_transitions" rel="nofollow">CSS transitions</a>
- <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#history" rel="nofollow">history support</a>

fixi takes advantage of some modern JavaScript features not used by htmx:

- <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/async_function" rel="nofollow"><code>async</code> functions</a>
- The <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API" rel="nofollow"><code>fetch()</code> API</a>
- The use of <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MutationObserver" rel="nofollow"><code>MutationObserver</code></a> for monitoring when new content is added
- The <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/View_Transition_API" rel="nofollow">View Transition API</a> (used by htmx, but the sole mechanism for transitions in fixi)

A hard constraint on the project is that the *unminified*, *uncompressed* size must be less than that of the minified & compressed version of the (excellent) <a href="https://bundlephobia.com/package/preact" rel="nofollow">preact library</a> (currently 4.6Kb).

The current uncompressed size is `3292` bytes, the gzipped size is `1398` bytes and the brotli'd size is `1181` bytes, as determined by:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ls -l fixi.js | awk  '{print &quot;raw:&quot;, $5}'; gzip -k fixi.js; ls -l fixi.js.gz | awk  '{print &quot;gzipped:&quot;, $5}'; rm fixi.js.gz; brotli fixi.js; ls -l fixi.js.br | awk  '{print &quot;brotlid:&quot;, $5}'; rm fixi.js.br">

    ls -l fixi.js | awk  '{print "raw:", $5}'; gzip -k fixi.js; ls -l fixi.js.gz | awk  '{print "gzipped:", $5}'; rm fixi.js.gz; brotli fixi.js; ls -l fixi.js.br | awk  '{print "brotlid:", $5}'; rm fixi.js.br

</div>

Another goal is that users should be able to <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/javascript/" rel="nofollow">debug</a> fixi easily, since it is small enough to use unminified.

The code style is [dense](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/fixi.js), but the statements are structured for debugging.

Like a fixed-gear bike, fixi has very few moving parts:

- No dependencies (including test and development)
- No JavaScript API (beyond the [events](#events))
- No minified `fixi.min.js` file
- No `package.json`
- No build step

The fixi project consists of three files:

- [`fixi.js`](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/fixi.js), the code for the library
- [`test.html`](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/test.html), the test suite for the library
- This [`README.md`](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/README.md), which is the documentation

[`test.html`](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/test.html) is a stand-alone HTML file that implements its own visual testing infrastructure, mocking for `fetch()`, etc. and that can be opened using the `file:` protocol for easy testing.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## Installing

<a href="#installing" id="user-content-installing" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Installing"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi is designed to be easily <a href="https://htmx.org/essays/vendoring/" rel="nofollow">vendored</a>, that is, copied, into your project:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bigskysoftware/fixi/refs/tags/0.9.2/fixi.js &gt;&gt; fixi-0.9.2.js">

    curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bigskysoftware/fixi/refs/tags/0.9.2/fixi.js >> fixi-0.9.2.js

</div>

The SHA256 of v0.9.2 is

`0957yKwrGW4niRASx0/UxJxBY/xBhYK63vDCnTF7hH4=`

generated by the following command line script:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="cat fixi.js | openssl sha256 -binary | openssl base64">

    cat fixi.js | openssl sha256 -binary | openssl base64

</div>

Alternatively can download the source from here:

<https://github.com/bigskysoftware/fixi/archive/refs/tags/0.9.2.zip>

You can also use the JSDelivr CDN for local development or testing:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;script src=&quot;https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/bigskysoftware/fixi@0.9.2/fixi.js&quot;
        crossorigin=&quot;anonymous&quot;
        integrity=&quot;sha256-0957yKwrGW4niRASx0/UxJxBY/xBhYK63vDCnTF7hH4=&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;">

    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/bigskysoftware/fixi@0.9.2/fixi.js"
            crossorigin="anonymous"
            integrity="sha256-0957yKwrGW4niRASx0/UxJxBY/xBhYK63vDCnTF7hH4="></script>

</div>

Finally, fixi is available on NPM as the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/fixi-js" rel="nofollow"><code>fixi-js</code></a> package.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## Support

<a href="#support" id="user-content-support" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Support"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

You can get support for fixi via:

- [Github Issues](https://github.com/bigskysoftware/fixi/issues)
- <a href="https://htmx.org/discord" rel="nofollow">The htmx Discord <code>#fixi</code> channel</a>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## API

<a href="#api" id="user-content-api" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: API"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Attributes

<a href="#attributes" id="user-content-attributes" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Attributes"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

| attribute | description | example |
|----|----|----|
| `fx-action` | The URL to which an HTTP request will be issued, required | `fx-action='/demo'` |
| `fx-method` | The HTTP Method that will be used for the request (case-insensitive), defaults to `GET` | `fx-method='DELETE'` |
| `fx-target` | A CSS selector specifying where to place the response HTML in the DOM, defaults to the current element | `fx-target='#a-div'` |
| `fx-swap` | A string specifying how the content should be swapped into the DOM, can be one of `innerHTML`, `outerHTML`, `beforebegin`, `afterbegin`, `beforeend`, `afterend`, `none`, or any valid property on the element (e.g. \`className\` or \`value\`), defaults to `outerHTML` | `fx-swap='innerHTML'` |
| `fx-trigger` | The event that will trigger a request, defaults to `submit` for `form` elements, `change` for `input`-like elements & `click` for all other elements | `fx-trigger='click'` |
| `fx-ignore` | Any element with this attribute on it or on an ancestor will not be processed for `fx-*` attributes |  |

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### Modus Operandi

<a href="#modus-operandi" id="user-content-modus-operandi" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Modus Operandi"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi works in a straight-forward manner & I encourage you to look at [the source](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/fixi.js) as you read through this. The three components of fixi are:

- [Processing](#processing) elements in the DOM (or added to the DOM)
- Issuing HTTP [requests](#requests) in response to events
- [Swapping](#swapping) new HTML content into the DOM

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### Processing

<a href="#processing" id="user-content-processing" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Processing"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The main entry point is found at the bottom of [fixi.js](/bigskysoftware/fixi/blob/master/fixi.js): on the `DOMContentLoaded` event fixi does two things:

- It has a MutationObserver begin to watch for newly added content with fixi-powered elements
- It processes any existing fixi-powered elements

fixi-powered elements are elements with the `fx-action` attribute on them.

When fixi finds one it will establish an event listener on that element that will dispatch an AJAX request via `fetch()` to the URL specified by `fx-action`.

fixi will ignore any elements that have the `fx-ignore` attribute on them or on an ancestor.

The event that will trigger the request is determined by the `fx-trigger` attribute.

If that attribute is not present, the trigger defaults to:

- `submit` for `form` elements
- `change` for `input:not([type=button])`, `select` & `textarea` elements
- `click` for everything else.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### Requests

<a href="#requests" id="user-content-requests" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Requests"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

When a request is triggered, the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Methods" rel="nofollow">HTTP method</a> of the request will be determined by the `fx-method` attribute. If this attribute is not present, it will default to `GET`. This attribute is case-insensitive.

fixi sends the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers" rel="nofollow">request header</a> `FX-Request`, with the value `true`. You can add or remove headers using the `evt.detail.cfg.headers` object, see the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event below.

If an element is within a form element or has a `form` attribute, the values of that form will be included with the request. Otherwise, if the element has a `name`, its `name` & `value` will be sent with the request. You can add or remove values using the `evt.detail.cfg.form` `FormData` object in the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event.

`GET` & `DELETE` requests will include values via query parameters, other request types will submit them as a form encoded body.

Before a request is sent, the aforementioned [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event is triggered, which can be used to configure aspects of the request. If `preventDefault()` is invoked in this event, the request will not be sent. The `evt.detail.cfg.drop` property will be <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Truthy" rel="nofollow">truthy</a> if there is an existing outstanding request associated with the element, otherwise the value will be <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Falsy" rel="nofollow">falsy</a>. More specifically, the value is equal to the number of outstanding requests associated with the element. If the value is truthy after the last `fx:config` handler has ran to completion, the request will be dropped (i.e. not issued). This implies, if you do not [customize the behavior](#replace-existing-requests-in-flight), an element will drop all new requests whilst there is an outstanding request associated with it.

In the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event you can also set the `evt.detail.cfg.confirm` property to a no-argument function. This function can return a Promise and can be used to asynchronously confirm that the request should be issued:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="function showAsynConfirmDialog() {
    //... a Promise-based confirmation dialog...
}

document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
    evt.detail.cfg.confirm = showAsynConfirmDialog;
})">

    function showAsynConfirmDialog() {
        //... a Promise-based confirmation dialog...
    }

    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
        evt.detail.cfg.confirm = showAsynConfirmDialog;
    })

</div>

Note that confirmation will only occur if the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event is not canceled and the request is not dropped.

After the configuration step and the confirmation, if any, the [`fx:before`](#fxbefore) event will be triggered, and then a `fetch()` will be issued. The `evt.detail.cfg` object from the events above is passed to the `fetch()` function as the second <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/RequestInit" rel="nofollow">RequestInit</a> argument.

When fixi receives a response it triggers the [`fx:after`](#fxafter) event.

In this event there are two more properties available on `evt.detail.cfg`:

- `response` the fetch <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response" rel="nofollow">Response</a> object
- `text` the text of the response

These can be inspected, and the `text` value can be changed if you want to transform it in some way.

If a network error occurs the [`fx:error`](#fxerror) event will be triggered instead of `fx:after`, and nothing will be swapped.

Note that `fetch()` only triggers errors <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/fetch" rel="nofollow">when a request fails due to a bad URL or network error</a>, so valid HTTP responses with non-`200` response codes will not trigger an error.

If you wish to handle non-200 reponses differently you should check the response code in the `fx:after` event:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:after&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  // rewire 404s to the body, remove current head so new head can replace it
  if (evt.detail.cfg.response.status == 404){
    document.head.remove()
    evt.detail.cfg.target = document.body
    evt.detail.cfg.swap = 'outerHTML'
  }
})">

    document.addEventListener("fx:after", (evt)=>{
      // rewire 404s to the body, remove current head so new head can replace it
      if (evt.detail.cfg.response.status == 404){
        document.head.remove()
        evt.detail.cfg.target = document.body
        evt.detail.cfg.swap = 'outerHTML'
      }
    })

</div>

The [`fx:finally`](#fxfinally) event will be triggered regardless if an error occurs or not.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### Swapping

<a href="#swapping" id="user-content-swapping" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Swapping"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi then swaps the response text into the DOM using the mechanism specified by `fx-swap`, targeting the element specified by `fx-target`. If the `fx-swap` attribute is not present, fixi will use `outerHTML`.

If the `fx-target` attribute is not present, it will target the element making the request.

The swap mechanism and target can be changed in the request-related fixi events.

You can implement a custom swapping mechanism by setting a function into the `evt.detail.cfg.swap` property in one of the request related events. This function should take one argument that will be set to the fixi request config itself.\
On that object you can access the `target`, `text`, `request`, etc. You can see an [example below](#custom-swapping-algorithms) showing how to do this.

By default, swapping will occur in a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/View_Transition_API" rel="nofollow">View Transition</a> if they are available. If you don't want this to occur, you can set the `evt.detail.cfg.transition` property to false in one of the request-related events.

Finally, when the swap and any associated View Transitions have completed, the `fx:swapped` event will be triggered on the element. If the element has been removed from the DOM, the event will also be triggered on `document`, which allows you to listen for this event on `document` and receive it after every swap.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

###### Notes on Targeting the Document Element (`html`)

<a href="#notes-on-targeting-the-document-element-html" id="user-content-notes-on-targeting-the-document-element-html" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Notes on Targeting the Document Element (html)"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Note that if you want to replace the entire document (that is, target the `html` element) you *must* use an `innerHTML` swap, because the default `outerHTML` swap will fail with a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException#nomodificationallowederror" rel="nofollow"><code>NoModificationAllowed</code></a> error.

If you wish to default the swap mechanism to `innerHTML` when targeting the `html` you can use this code:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
    if (evt.detail.cfg.target === document.documentElement){
        evt.detail.cfg.swap = &quot;innerHTML&quot;
    }
})">

    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
        if (evt.detail.cfg.target === document.documentElement){
            evt.detail.cfg.swap = "innerHTML"
        }
    })

</div>

Note also that if you replace the `head` tag, due to the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/innerHTML#security_considerations" rel="nofollow">quirks of the DOM API specification</a>, styles *will* be updated, but *scripts* will not be executed.

You must therefore manually manage and execute any script tags:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
    if (evt.detail.cfg.target === document.documentElement){
        let scripts = document.head.querySelectorAll(&quot;script&quot;);
        for(let script of scripts) { 
            let newScript = document.createRange().createContextualFragment(script.outerHTML)
            document.head.insertBefore(newScript, script)
            script.remove()
        }
    }
})">

    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
        if (evt.detail.cfg.target === document.documentElement){
            let scripts = document.head.querySelectorAll("script");
            for(let script of scripts) { 
                let newScript = document.createRange().createContextualFragment(script.outerHTML)
                document.head.insertBefore(newScript, script)
                script.remove()
            }
        }
    })

</div>

For inline scripts where <a href="https://htmx.org/essays/locality-of-behaviour" rel="nofollow">Locality of Behavior</a> is desired. The target scripts need to be replaced in order to execute.

This will automatically execute all script tags that are swapped in:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener('fx:swapped', (evt) =&gt; {
    evt.detail.cfg.target.querySelectorAll('script').forEach(s =&gt;
        s.replaceWith(Object.assign(document.createElement('script'),{textContent:s.textContent}))
    )
})">

    document.addEventListener('fx:swapped', (evt) => {
        evt.detail.cfg.target.querySelectorAll('script').forEach(s =>
            s.replaceWith(Object.assign(document.createElement('script'),{textContent:s.textContent}))
        )
    })

</div>

However, these simple approaches may fail if you have scripts that, for example, create global variables with `let`, etc.

For this reason we broadly recommend loading all your scripts up front or simply using anchor tags for full page navigations, unless you want to get into the weeds of dealing with these issues.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### Complete Example

<a href="#complete-example" id="user-content-complete-example" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Complete Example"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Here is a complete example using all the attributes available in fixi:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; fx-method=&quot;GET&quot; 
        fx-target=&quot;#output&quot; fx-swap=&quot;innerHTML&quot; 
        fx-trigger=&quot;click&quot;&gt;
    Get Content
&lt;/button&gt;
&lt;output id=&quot;output&quot; fx-ignore&gt;--&lt;/output&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/demo" fx-method="GET" 
            fx-target="#output" fx-swap="innerHTML" 
            fx-trigger="click">
        Get Content
    </button>
    <output id="output" fx-ignore>--</output>

</div>

In this example, the button will issue a `GET` request to `/demo` and put the resulting HTML into the `innerHTML` of the output element with the id `output`.

Because the `output` element is marked as `fx-ignore`, any `fx-action` attributes in the new content will be ignored.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Events

<a href="#events" id="user-content-events" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Events"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi fires the following events, broken into two categories:

<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>category</th>
<th>event</th>
<th>description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3"><a href="#initialization-events">initialization</a></td>
<td><a href="#fxinit"><code>fx:init</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on elements that have a <code>fx-action</code> attribute and are about to be initialized by fixi</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxinited"><code>fx:inited</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on elements have been initialized by fixi (does <strong>not</strong> bubble)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxprocess"><code>fx:process</code></a></td>
<td>fixi listens on the <code>document</code> object for this event and will process (that is, enable any fixi-powered elements) within that element.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="6"><a href="#fetch-events">fetch</a></td>
<td><a href="#fxconfig"><code>fx:config</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on an element immediately when a request has been triggered, allowing users to configure the request</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxbefore"><code>fx:before</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on an element just before a <code>fetch()</code> request is made</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxafter"><code>fx:after</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on an element just after a <code>fetch()</code> request finishes normally but before content is swapped</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxerror"><code>fx:error</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on an element if something is thrown from a <code>fetch()</code></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxfinally"><code>fx:finally</code></a></td>
<td>triggered on an element after a request no matter what</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#fxswapped"><code>fx:swapped</code></a></td>
<td>triggered after the swap and any associated <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/View_Transition_API" rel="nofollow">View Transition</a> has completed</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### Initialization Events

<a href="#initialization-events" id="user-content-initialization-events" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Initialization Events"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:init`

<a href="#fxinit" id="user-content-fxinit" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:init"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:init` event is triggered when fixi is processing a node with an `fx-action` attribute. One property is available in `evt.detail`:

- `options` - An <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener#options" rel="nofollow">Options Object</a> that will be passed to `addEventListener()`

If this event is cancelled via `preventDefault()`, the element will not be initialized by fixi.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:inited`

<a href="#fxinited" id="user-content-fxinited" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:inited"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:inited` event is triggered when fixi finished processing a node with an `fx-action` attribute.

Unlike other fixi events, this event does not bubble.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:process`

<a href="#fxprocess" id="user-content-fxprocess" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:process"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi listens for the `fx:process` event on the `document` and will enable any unprocessed fixi-powered elements within the element as well as the element itself.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### Fetch Events

<a href="#fetch-events" id="user-content-fetch-events" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Fetch Events"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi uses the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API" rel="nofollow"><code>fetch()</code> API</a> to issue HTTP requests. It triggers events around this call that allow users to configure the request.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:config`

<a href="#fxconfig" id="user-content-fxconfig" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:config"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The first event triggered is `fx:config`. This event can be used to configure the arguments passed to `fetch()` via the fixi config object, which can be found at `evt.detail.cfg`.

This config object has the following properties:

- `trigger` - The event that triggered the request
- `method` - The HTTP Method that is going to be used
- `action` - The URL that the request is going to be issued to
- `headers` - An Object of name/value pairs to be sent as HTTP Request Headers
- `target` - The target element that will be swapped when the response is processed
- `swap` - The mechanism by which the element will be swapped
- `body` - The body of the request, if present, a FormData object that holds the data of the form associated with the request
- `drop` - Whether this request will be dropped, defaults to the number of outstanding requests associated with the element
- `transition` - The View Transition function, if it is available. Set to `false` if you don't want a transition to occur
- `preventTrigger` - A boolean (defaults to `true`) that, if true, will call `preventDefault()` on the triggering event
- `signal` - The AbortSignal of the related AbortController for the request
- `abort()` - A function that can be invoked to abort the pending fetch request
- `fetch()` - The fetch() function that will be used for the request, can be used for [mocking](#mocking) requests

Mutating the `method`, etc. properties of the `cfg` object will change the behavior of the request dynamically. Note that the `cfg` object is passed to `fetch()` as the second argument of type `RequestInit`, so any properties you want to set on the `RequestInit` may be set on the `cfg` object (e.g. `credentials`).

Another property available on the `detail` of this event is `requests`, which will be a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Set" rel="nofollow">Set</a> of any existing outstanding requests for the element.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

###### replace existing requests in flight

<a href="#replace-existing-requests-in-flight" id="user-content-replace-existing-requests-in-flight" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: replace existing requests in flight"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi does not implement request queuing like htmx does, but you can implement a simple "replace existing requests in flight" rule with the following JavaScript:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
    evt.detail.cfg.drop = 0;  // allow this request to be issued even if there are other requests
    evt.detail.requests.forEach((cfg) =&gt; cfg.abort()); // abort all existing requests
})">

    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
        evt.detail.cfg.drop = 0;  // allow this request to be issued even if there are other requests
        evt.detail.requests.forEach((cfg) => cfg.abort()); // abort all existing requests
    })

</div>

If you call `preventDefault()` on this event, no request will be issued.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:before`

<a href="#fxbefore" id="user-content-fxbefore" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:before"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:before` event is triggered just before a `fetch()` is issued. The config will again be available in the `evt.detail.cfg` property, but after any confirmation is done. The requests will also be available in `evt.detail.requests` and will include the current request.

If you call `preventDefault()` on this event, no request will be issued.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:after`

<a href="#fxafter" id="user-content-fxafter" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:after"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:after` event is triggered after a `fetch()` successfully completes. The config will again be available in the `evt.detail.cfg` property, and will have two additional properties:

- `response` - The response object from the `fetch()` call
- `text` - The text of the response

At this point you may still mutate the `swap`, etc. attributes to affect swapping, and you may mutate the `text` if you want to modify it is some way before it is swapped.

Calling `preventDefault()` on this event will prevent swapping from occurring.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:error`

<a href="#fxerror" id="user-content-fxerror" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:error"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:error` event is triggered when a network error occurs or when the request is aborted using the `abort` function on the config. In this case the `evt.detail.cfg` object is available for modification and `cfg.response` and `cfg.text` will not be present. The `evt.detail.error` property contains the thrown value. If you receive this event, swapping will not occur, the processing is terminated early.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:finally`

<a href="#fxfinally" id="user-content-fxfinally" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:finally"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:finally` event is triggered regardless if an error occurs or not and can be used to clean up after a request. Again the `evt.detail.cfg` object is available for modification.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

##### `fx:swapped`

<a href="#fxswapped" id="user-content-fxswapped" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: fx:swapped"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `fx:swapped` event is triggered once the swap and any associated View Transitions complete. The `evt.detail.cfg` object is available.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Properties

<a href="#properties" id="user-content-properties" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Properties"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi adds two properties to elements in the DOM

| property | description |
|----|----|
| [`document.__fixi_mo`](#document__fixi_mo) | The MutationObserver that fixi uses to watch for new content to process new fixi-powered elements. |
| [`elt.__fixi`](#elt__fixi) | The event handler created by fixi on fixi-powered elements |

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### `document.__fixi_mo`

<a href="#document__fixi_mo" id="user-content-document__fixi_mo" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: document.__fixi_mo"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi stores the Mutation Observer that it uses to watch for new content in the `__fixi_mo` property on the `document`.

You can use this property to temporarily disable mutation observation for performance reasons:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// disable processing
document.__fixi_mo.disconnect()

/* ... heavy mutation code that should not be processed by fixi */

// reenable processing
document.__fixi_mo.observe(document.body, {childList:true, subtree:true})">

    // disable processing
    document.__fixi_mo.disconnect()

    /* ... heavy mutation code that should not be processed by fixi */

    // reenable processing
    document.__fixi_mo.observe(document.body, {childList:true, subtree:true})

</div>

Similar code can be used to adjust the MutationObserver to listen for mutations in some subset of the document.

Finally, you can also switch to entirely manual processing using the [`fx:after`](#fxafter), [`fx:swapped`](#fxswapped) & [`fx:process`](#fxprocess) events:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.__fixi_mo.disconnect()
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:after&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  // capture the parent element of the target in the config before swapping
  evt.detail.cfg.parent = evt.detail.cfg.target.parentElement
})
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:swapped&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  // reprocess the parent
  evt.detail.cfg.parent.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;fx:process&quot;), {bubbles:true})
})">

    document.__fixi_mo.disconnect()
    document.addEventListener("fx:after", (evt)=>{
      // capture the parent element of the target in the config before swapping
      evt.detail.cfg.parent = evt.detail.cfg.target.parentElement
    })
    document.addEventListener("fx:swapped", (evt)=>{
      // reprocess the parent
      evt.detail.cfg.parent.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("fx:process"), {bubbles:true})
    })

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### `elt.__fixi`

<a href="#elt__fixi" id="user-content-elt__fixi" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: elt.__fixi"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The `__fixi` property will be added to any element that has an `fx-action` attribute on it assuming that the element or an ancestor is not marked `fx-ignore`.

The value of the property will be the event listener that is added to the element. It also has two properties:

- `evt` - the string event name that will trigger the handler
- `requests` - the config values of any open requests (may be `null`)

This property can be used to remove the fixi-generated event handler like so:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="elt.removeEventListener(elt.__fixi.evt, elt.__fixi)">

    elt.removeEventListener(elt.__fixi.evt, elt.__fixi)

</div>

If you want to reprocess the element you will need to remove the property entirely and trigger the [`fx:process`](#fxprocess) event on it:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="elt.removeEventListener(elt.__fixi.evt, elt.__fixi)
delete elt.__fixi
elt.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;fx:process&quot;), {bubbles:true})">

    elt.removeEventListener(elt.__fixi.evt, elt.__fixi)
    delete elt.__fixi
    elt.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("fx:process"), {bubbles:true})

</div>

You can also use this property to store extension-related information. See the [polling example](#polling) below.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## Mocking

<a href="#mocking" id="user-content-mocking" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Mocking"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

It is easy to mock `fetch()` requests in fixi by replacing the `evt.detail.cfg.fetch` property with a mocking function. The function can take the same arguments as <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API" rel="nofollow"><code>fetch()</code></a> (or not if they are not needed) and should return a <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response" rel="nofollow"><code>Response</code></a> compatible object or a Promise that resolves to one.

For the simple case, the return object need only implement the `.text()` method.

Here is an example that mocks responses using `template` elements

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
   const template = document.getElementById(evt.detail.cfg.action)
   if (template) {
     evt.detail.cfg.fetch = ()=&gt;({text:  ()=&gt;template.innerHTML}) // note the parens to make {} an object
   }
 })">

    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
       const template = document.getElementById(evt.detail.cfg.action)
       if (template) {
         evt.detail.cfg.fetch = ()=>({text:  ()=>template.innerHTML}) // note the parens to make {} an object
       }
     })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot;&gt;
    Replace Me With A Template
&lt;/button&gt;
&lt;template id=&quot;/demo&quot;&gt;
    Some Template Content...
&lt;/template&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/demo">
        Replace Me With A Template
    </button>
    <template id="/demo">
        Some Template Content...
    </template>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

## Examples

<a href="#examples" id="user-content-examples" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Examples"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Here are some basic examples of fixi in action

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Click To Edit

<a href="#click-to-edit" id="user-content-click-to-edit" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Click To Edit"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The htmx <a href="https://htmx.org/examples/click-to-edit/" rel="nofollow">click to edit example</a> can be easily ported to fixi:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;div id=&quot;target-div&quot;&gt;
    &lt;div&gt;&lt;label&gt;First Name&lt;/label&gt;: Joe&lt;/div&gt;
    &lt;div&gt;&lt;label&gt;Last Name&lt;/label&gt;: Blow&lt;/div&gt;
    &lt;div&gt;&lt;label&gt;Email&lt;/label&gt;: joe@blow.com&lt;/div&gt;
    &lt;button fx-action=&quot;/contact/1/edit&quot; fx-target=&quot;#target-div&quot; class=&quot;btn primary&quot;&gt;
    Click To Edit
    &lt;/button&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;">

    <div id="target-div">
        <div><label>First Name</label>: Joe</div>
        <div><label>Last Name</label>: Blow</div>
        <div><label>Email</label>: joe@blow.com</div>
        <button fx-action="/contact/1/edit" fx-target="#target-div" class="btn primary">
        Click To Edit
        </button>
    </div>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Delete Row

<a href="#delete-row" id="user-content-delete-row" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Delete Row"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The <a href="https://htmx.org/examples/delete-row/" rel="nofollow">delete row example</a> from htmx can be implemented in fixi like so:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;tr id=&quot;row-1&quot;&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;Angie MacDowell&lt;/td&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;angie@macdowell.org&lt;/td&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;Active&lt;/td&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;
    &lt;button class=&quot;btn danger&quot; fx-action=&quot;/contact/1&quot; fx-method=&quot;delete&quot; fx-target=&quot;#row-1&quot;&gt;

    &lt;/button&gt;
  &lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;">

    <tr id="row-1">
      <td>Angie MacDowell</td>
      <td>angie@macdowell.org</td>
      <td>Active</td>
      <td>
        <button class="btn danger" fx-action="/contact/1" fx-method="delete" fx-target="#row-1">
          Delete
        </button>
      </td>
    </tr>

</div>

Note that this version does not have a confirmation prompt, you would need to implement that yourself using the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event.

## Extensions

<a href="#extensions" id="user-content-extensions" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Extensions"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Because fixi is minimalistic the user is responsible for implementing many behaviors they want via events. We have already seen how to abort an existing request that is already in flight.

A suggested convention when you are adding fixi extension attributes is to use the `ext-fx` prefix, and to process the extension in the `fx:init` method. You may find it useful to use the `__fixi` property on the element to store values necessary for the extension to work.

Another suggested convention is keeping your fixi extensions in a single file called `ext-fixi.js` alongside your `fixi-<version>.js` file.

Here are some examples of useful fixi extensions implemented using events.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Disabling an Element During A Request

<a href="#disabling-an-element-during-a-request" id="user-content-disabling-an-element-during-a-request" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Disabling an Element During A Request"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Here is an example that will use attributes to disable an element when a request is in flight:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi disable elements extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:init&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  if (evt.target.matches(&quot;[ext-fx-disable]&quot;)){
    var disableSelector = evt.target.getAttribute('ext-fx-disable')
    evt.target.addEventListener('fx:before', ()=&gt;{
      let disableTarget = disableSelector == &quot;&quot; ? evt.target : document.querySelector(disableSelector)
      disableTarget.disabled = true
      evt.target.addEventListener('fx:after', (afterEvt)=&gt;{
        if (afterEvt.target == evt.target){
          disableTarget.disabled = false
        }
      })
    })
  }
})">

    // fixi disable elements extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:init", (evt)=>{
      if (evt.target.matches("[ext-fx-disable]")){
        var disableSelector = evt.target.getAttribute('ext-fx-disable')
        evt.target.addEventListener('fx:before', ()=>{
          let disableTarget = disableSelector == "" ? evt.target : document.querySelector(disableSelector)
          disableTarget.disabled = true
          evt.target.addEventListener('fx:after', (afterEvt)=>{
            if (afterEvt.target == evt.target){
              disableTarget.disabled = false
            }
          })
        })
      }
    })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; ext-fx-disable&gt;
  Demo
&lt;/button&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/demo" ext-fx-disable>
      Demo
    </button>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Showing an Indicator During A Request

<a href="#showing-an-indicator-during-a-request" id="user-content-showing-an-indicator-during-a-request" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Showing an Indicator During A Request"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

Here is an example that will use attributes a `fixi-request-in-flight` class to show an indicator of some kind:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi request indicator extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:init&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  if (evt.target.matches(&quot;[ext-fx-indicator]&quot;)){
    var disableSelector = evt.target.getAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-indicator&quot;)
    evt.target.addEventListener(&quot;fx:before&quot;, ()=&gt;{
      let disableTarget = disableSelector == &quot;&quot; ? evt.target : document.querySelector(disableSelector)
      disableTarget.classList.add(&quot;fixi-request-in-flight&quot;)
      evt.target.addEventListener(&quot;fx:after&quot;, (afterEvt)=&gt;{
        if (afterEvt.target == evt.target){
          disableTarget.classList.remove(&quot;fixi-request-in-flight&quot;)
        }
      })
    })
  }
})">

    // fixi request indicator extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:init", (evt)=>{
      if (evt.target.matches("[ext-fx-indicator]")){
        var disableSelector = evt.target.getAttribute("ext-fx-indicator")
        evt.target.addEventListener("fx:before", ()=>{
          let disableTarget = disableSelector == "" ? evt.target : document.querySelector(disableSelector)
          disableTarget.classList.add("fixi-request-in-flight")
          evt.target.addEventListener("fx:after", (afterEvt)=>{
            if (afterEvt.target == evt.target){
              disableTarget.classList.remove("fixi-request-in-flight")
            }
          })
        })
      }
    })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;style&gt;
  #indicator {
    display: none;
  }
  #indicator.fixi-request-in-flight {
    display: inline-block;
  }
&lt;/style&gt;
&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; ext-fx-indicator=&quot;#indicator&quot;&gt;
    Demo
   &lt;img src=&quot;spinner.gif&quot; id=&quot;indicator&quot;&gt;
&lt;/button&gt;">

    <style>
      #indicator {
        display: none;
      }
      #indicator.fixi-request-in-flight {
        display: inline-block;
      }
    </style>
    <button fx-action="/demo" ext-fx-indicator="#indicator">
        Demo
       <img src="spinner.gif" id="indicator">
    </button>

</div>

This example can be modified to use classes or other mechanisms for showing indicators as well.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Debouncing A Request

<a href="#debouncing-a-request" id="user-content-debouncing-a-request" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Debouncing A Request"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

The following extension allows you to <a href="https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/debouncing-in-javascript/" rel="nofollow">debounce</a> the triggering event for a fixi-powered element. It does this by removing the initial listener installed by fixi and wiring in a new listener for the same event that delegates to the fixi handler if no other events occur in the given time period. The debouncing time is specified via the `ext-fx-debounce` attribute, which specified the number of milliseconds to wait before triggering the request.

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi event debouncing extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:init&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
    let target = evt.target
    // if this element has the debounce extention
    if (target.hasAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-debounce&quot;)){
        // add a listener for the fx:inited event, when the __fixi property is available
        target.addEventListener(&quot;fx:inited&quot;, ()=&gt;{
            // remove the default listener 
            target.removeEventListener(target.__fixi.evt, target.__fixi)
            let debounceTime = parseInt(target.getAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-debounce&quot;))
            let timeout = null
            // install a debounced version that delegates to the default listener 
            target.addEventListener(target.__fixi.evt, (evt)=&gt;{
                clearTimeout(timeout)
                timeout = setTimeout(()=&gt;target.__fixi(evt), debounceTime)
            })
        })
    }
})">

    // fixi event debouncing extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:init", (evt)=>{
        let target = evt.target
        // if this element has the debounce extention
        if (target.hasAttribute("ext-fx-debounce")){
            // add a listener for the fx:inited event, when the __fixi property is available
            target.addEventListener("fx:inited", ()=>{
                // remove the default listener 
                target.removeEventListener(target.__fixi.evt, target.__fixi)
                let debounceTime = parseInt(target.getAttribute("ext-fx-debounce"))
                let timeout = null
                // install a debounced version that delegates to the default listener 
                target.addEventListener(target.__fixi.evt, (evt)=>{
                    clearTimeout(timeout)
                    timeout = setTimeout(()=>target.__fixi(evt), debounceTime)
                })
            })
        }
    })

</div>

Here is an implementation of the <a href="https://htmx.org/examples/active-search/" rel="nofollow">active search</a> example from the htmx website using this extension:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;form action=&quot;/search&quot; fx-action=&quot;/search&quot; fx-target=&quot;#results&quot; fx-swap=&quot;innerHTML&quot;&gt;
  &lt;input id=&quot;search&quot; type=&quot;search&quot; fx-action=&quot;/search&quot; fx-trigger=&quot;input&quot; ext-fx-debounce=&quot;200&quot; fx-target=&quot;#results&quot; fx-swap=&quot;innerHTML&quot;/&gt;
  &lt;button type=&quot;submit&quot;&gt;
    Search
  &lt;/button&gt;
&lt;/form&gt;
&lt;table&gt;
  ...
  &lt;tbody id=&quot;results&quot;&gt;
  ...
  &lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;">

    <form action="/search" fx-action="/search" fx-target="#results" fx-swap="innerHTML">
      <input id="search" type="search" fx-action="/search" fx-trigger="input" ext-fx-debounce="200" fx-target="#results" fx-swap="innerHTML"/>
      <button type="submit">
        Search
      </button>
    </form>
    <table>
      ...
      <tbody id="results">
      ...
      </tbody>
    </table>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Polling

<a href="#polling" id="user-content-polling" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Polling"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

htmx-style polling can be implemented in the following manner:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi polling extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:init&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
  let elt = evt.target
  if (elt.matches(&quot;[ext-fx-poll-interval]&quot;)){
    // wait for the non-bubbling fx:inited event on the element so the __fixi property is available
    elt.addEventListener(&quot;fx:inited&quot;, ()=&gt;{
        // squirrel away in case we want to call clearInterval() later
        elt.__fixi.pollInterval = setInterval(()=&gt;{
            elt.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;poll&quot;))
        }, parseInt(elt.getAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-poll-interval&quot;)))
    })
  }
})">

    // fixi polling extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:init", (evt)=>{
      let elt = evt.target
      if (elt.matches("[ext-fx-poll-interval]")){
        // wait for the non-bubbling fx:inited event on the element so the __fixi property is available
        elt.addEventListener("fx:inited", ()=>{
            // squirrel away in case we want to call clearInterval() later
            elt.__fixi.pollInterval = setInterval(()=>{
                elt.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("poll"))
            }, parseInt(elt.getAttribute("ext-fx-poll-interval")))
        })
      }
    })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;h3&gt;Live News&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;div fx-action=&quot;/news&quot; fx-trigger=&quot;poll&quot; ext-fx-poll-interval=&quot;300&quot;&gt;
  ... initial content ...
&lt;/div&gt;">

    <h3>Live News</h3>
    <div fx-action="/news" fx-trigger="poll" ext-fx-poll-interval="300">
      ... initial content ...
    </div>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Server Sent Events

<a href="#server-sent-events" id="user-content-server-sent-events" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Server Sent Events"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Server-sent_events" rel="nofollow">SSE</a>-based swaps can be implemented in the following manner:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="const evtSource = new EventSource(&quot;/sse&quot;);
evtSource.addEventListener(&quot;fixi&quot;, (event) =&gt; {
  const { target, swap, text } = JSON.parse(event.data);
  document.querySelectorAll(target).forEach(async (ele) =&gt; {
    if (ele) {
      const cfg = {
        target: ele,
    swap: swap,
    text: text,
    transition: document.startViewTransition?.bind(document),
      };
      let doSwap = () =&gt; {
        if (/(before|after)(begin|end)/.test(cfg.swap))
      cfg.target.insertAdjacentHTML(cfg.swap, cfg.text);
    else if (cfg.swap in cfg.target)
      cfg.target[cfg.swap] = cfg.text;
    else throw cfg.swap;
      };
      if (cfg.transition) await cfg.transition(doSwap).finished;
      else await doSwap();
    }
  });
});">

    const evtSource = new EventSource("/sse");
    evtSource.addEventListener("fixi", (event) => {
      const { target, swap, text } = JSON.parse(event.data);
      document.querySelectorAll(target).forEach(async (ele) => {
        if (ele) {
          const cfg = {
            target: ele,
        swap: swap,
        text: text,
        transition: document.startViewTransition?.bind(document),
          };
          let doSwap = () => {
            if (/(before|after)(begin|end)/.test(cfg.swap))
          cfg.target.insertAdjacentHTML(cfg.swap, cfg.text);
        else if (cfg.swap in cfg.target)
          cfg.target[cfg.swap] = cfg.text;
        else throw cfg.swap;
          };
          if (cfg.transition) await cfg.transition(doSwap).finished;
          else await doSwap();
        }
      });
    });

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

#### Example Event

<a href="#example-event" id="user-content-example-event" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Example Event"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

On the server side, a fixi event type can be sent with a stringified object containing target, swap, and text.

<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="event: fixi
data: {&quot;target&quot;:&quot;#clock&quot;,&quot;swap&quot;:&quot;innerHTML&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Mon Jun 30 2025 14:23:58 GMT-0400 (Eastern Daylight Time)&quot;}
">

``` notranslate
event: fixi
data: {"target":"#clock","swap":"innerHTML","text":"Mon Jun 30 2025 14:23:58 GMT-0400 (Eastern Daylight Time)"}
```

</div>

### Confirmation

<a href="#confirmation" id="user-content-confirmation" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Confirmation"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

This extension implements a simple `confirm()` based confirmation if the `ext-fx-confirm` attribute is found. Note that it does not use a Promise, just the regular old blocking `confirm()` function

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi confirmation extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
    var confirmationMessage = evt.target.getAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-confirm&quot;)
    if (confirmationMessage){
        evt.detail.cfg.confirm = ()=&gt;confirm(confirmationMessage)
    }
})">

    // fixi confirmation extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt)=>{
        var confirmationMessage = evt.target.getAttribute("ext-fx-confirm")
        if (confirmationMessage){
            evt.detail.cfg.confirm = ()=>confirm(confirmationMessage)
        }
    })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; fx-method=&quot;delete&quot; ext-fx-confirm=&quot;Are you sure?&quot;&gt;
    Delete It
&lt;/button&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/demo" fx-method="delete" ext-fx-confirm="Are you sure?">
        Delete It
    </button>

</div>

### Relative Selectors

<a href="#relative-selectors" id="user-content-relative-selectors" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Relative Selectors"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

This extension implements relative selectors for the `fx-target` attribute.

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi relative selectors extension
document.addEventListener('fx:config', (evt)=&gt;{
    console.log(&quot;here&quot;)
    var target = evt.target.getAttribute(&quot;fx-target&quot;) || &quot;&quot;
    if (target.indexOf(&quot;closest &quot;) == 0){
        evt.detail.cfg.target = evt.target.closest(target.substring(8))
    } else if (target.indexOf(&quot;find &quot;) == 0){
        evt.detail.cfg.target = evt.target.querySelector(target.substring(5))
    } else if (target.indexOf(&quot;next &quot;) == 0){
        var matches = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll(target.substring(5)))
        evt.detail.cfg.target = matches.find((elt) =&gt; evt.target.compareDocumentPosition(elt) === Node.DOCUMENT_POSITION_FOLLOWING)
    } else if (target.indexOf(&quot;previous &quot;) == 0){
        var matches = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll(target.substring(9))).reverse()
        evt.detail.cfg.target = matches.find((elt) =&gt; evt.target.compareDocumentPosition(elt) === Node.DOCUMENT_POSITION_PRECEDING)
    }
})">

    // fixi relative selectors extension
    document.addEventListener('fx:config', (evt)=>{
        console.log("here")
        var target = evt.target.getAttribute("fx-target") || ""
        if (target.indexOf("closest ") == 0){
            evt.detail.cfg.target = evt.target.closest(target.substring(8))
        } else if (target.indexOf("find ") == 0){
            evt.detail.cfg.target = evt.target.querySelector(target.substring(5))
        } else if (target.indexOf("next ") == 0){
            var matches = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll(target.substring(5)))
            evt.detail.cfg.target = matches.find((elt) => evt.target.compareDocumentPosition(elt) === Node.DOCUMENT_POSITION_FOLLOWING)
        } else if (target.indexOf("previous ") == 0){
            var matches = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll(target.substring(9))).reverse()
            evt.detail.cfg.target = matches.find((elt) => evt.target.compareDocumentPosition(elt) === Node.DOCUMENT_POSITION_PRECEDING)
        }
    })

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; fx-target=&quot;next output&quot;&gt;
    Get Data
&lt;/button&gt;
&lt;output&gt;&lt;/output&gt;">

    <button fx-action="/demo" fx-target="next output">
        Get Data
    </button>
    <output></output>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Intersection Events

<a href="#intersection-events" id="user-content-intersection-events" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Intersection Events"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi does not trigger events when elements become visible like htmx does, but you can implement this behavior with the following extension. It adds an <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Intersection_Observer_API" rel="nofollow">IntersectionObserver</a> for every element with the `intersect` trigger and wires it in to trigger that event once the element intersects the viewport.

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi intersection events extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:init&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
    let trigger = evt.target.getAttribute(&quot;fx-trigger&quot;)
    if(trigger === &quot;intersect&quot;) {
        let obs = evt.target.__fixi_ob = new IntersectionObserver((entries)=&gt;{
            for(const entry of entries) {
                if (entry.isIntersecting){
                    // done observing, remove
                    obs.unobserve(evt.target)
                    evt.target.__fixi_ob = null;
                    // trigger event
                    evt.target.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;intersect&quot;))
                    return;
                }
            }
        })
        obs.observe(evt.target)
    }
})">

    // fixi intersection events extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:init", (evt) => {
        let trigger = evt.target.getAttribute("fx-trigger")
        if(trigger === "intersect") {
            let obs = evt.target.__fixi_ob = new IntersectionObserver((entries)=>{
                for(const entry of entries) {
                    if (entry.isIntersecting){
                        // done observing, remove
                        obs.unobserve(evt.target)
                        evt.target.__fixi_ob = null;
                        // trigger event
                        evt.target.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("intersect"))
                        return;
                    }
                }
            })
            obs.observe(evt.target)
        }
    })

</div>

With this extension it is possible to implement the <a href="https://htmx.org/examples/infinite-scroll/" rel="nofollow">infinite scroll</a> example:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;tr fx-action=&quot;/contacts/?page=2&quot;
    fx-trigger=&quot;intersect&quot;
    fx-swap=&quot;afterend&quot;&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;Agent Smith&lt;/td&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;void29@null.org&lt;/td&gt;
  &lt;td&gt;55F49448C0&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;">

    <tr fx-action="/contacts/?page=2"
        fx-trigger="intersect"
        fx-swap="afterend">
      <td>Agent Smith</td>
      <td>void29@null.org</td>
      <td>55F49448C0</td>
    </tr>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Custom Swapping Algorithms

<a href="#custom-swapping-algorithms" id="user-content-custom-swapping-algorithms" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Custom Swapping Algorithms"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

You can implement a custom swap strategies using the [`fx:config`](#fxconfig) event, and wiring in a function for the `evt.detail.cfg.swap` property. Here is an example that allows you to use [Idiomorph](https://github.com/bigskysoftware/idiomorph), a morphing algorithm, with the `morph` & `innerMorph` values in `fx-swap`:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// fixi morphing extension
document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:config&quot;, (evt) =&gt; {
  function morph(cfg, style) {
    Idiomorph.morph(cfg.target, cfg.text, { morphStyle: style }).forEach((n) =&gt; {
      // process nodes as morphing existing nodes will not trigger fixi MutationObserver
      n.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;fx:process&quot;, { bubbles: true }));
    });
  }
  if (evt.detail.cfg.swap == &quot;morph&quot;)
    evt.detail.cfg.swap = (cfg) =&gt; morph(cfg, &quot;outerHTML&quot;);
  if (evt.detail.cfg.swap == &quot;innerMorph&quot;)
    evt.detail.cfg.swap = (cfg) =&gt; morph(cfg, &quot;innerHTML&quot;);
});">

    // fixi morphing extension
    document.addEventListener("fx:config", (evt) => {
      function morph(cfg, style) {
        Idiomorph.morph(cfg.target, cfg.text, { morphStyle: style }).forEach((n) => {
          // process nodes as morphing existing nodes will not trigger fixi MutationObserver
          n.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("fx:process", { bubbles: true }));
        });
      }
      if (evt.detail.cfg.swap == "morph")
        evt.detail.cfg.swap = (cfg) => morph(cfg, "outerHTML");
      if (evt.detail.cfg.swap == "innerMorph")
        evt.detail.cfg.swap = (cfg) => morph(cfg, "innerHTML");
    });

</div>

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;h3&gt;Morph&lt;/h3&gt;
&lt;button fx-action=&quot;/demo&quot; fx-swap=&quot;morph&quot; fx-target=&quot;#output&quot;&gt;
  Morph New Content
&lt;/button&gt;
&lt;output id=&quot;output&quot;&gt;&lt;/output&gt;">

    <h3>Morph</h3>
    <button fx-action="/demo" fx-swap="morph" fx-target="#output">
      Morph New Content
    </button>
    <output id="output"></output>

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Implementing Attribute Inheritance

<a href="#implementing-attribute-inheritance" id="user-content-implementing-attribute-inheritance" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Implementing Attribute Inheritance"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi does not implement <a href="https://htmx.org/docs/#inheritance" rel="nofollow">attribute inheritance</a> like htmx does, but you can modify the fixi source to do so easily.

Simply change this line:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    let attr = (elt, name, defaultVal)=&gt;elt.getAttribute(name) || defaultVal">

        let attr = (elt, name, defaultVal)=>elt.getAttribute(name) || defaultVal

</div>

to this:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    let attr = (elt, name, defaultVal)=&gt;elt.closest(`[${name}]`)?.getAttribute(name) || defaultVal">

        let attr = (elt, name, defaultVal)=>elt.closest(`[${name}]`)?.getAttribute(name) || defaultVal

</div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

### Implementing History Support

<a href="#implementing-history-support" id="user-content-implementing-history-support" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Implementing History Support"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

</div>

fixi does not implement history support, but you can add rudimentary support like so:

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    function initJS() {
      // initialize javascript things here
    }
    document.addEventListener(&quot;DOMContentLoaded&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
        initJS();
    });
    document.addEventListener(&quot;fx:after&quot;, (evt)=&gt;{
        if (evt.target.hasAttribute(&quot;ext-fx-push&quot;)){
            history.replaceState({fixi:true, url:location.href}, &quot;&quot;, location.href)
            history.pushState({fixi:true, url:evt.detail.cfg.response.url}, &quot;&quot;, evt.detail.cfg.response.url)
        }
    })
    window.addEventListener(&quot;popstate&quot;, async(evt)=&gt;{
        if (evt.state.fixi){
            let historyResp = await fetch(evt.state.url)
            document.documentElement.innerHTML = await historyResp.text()
            document.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(&quot;fx:process&quot;))
            initJS()
        }
    })">

        function initJS() {
          // initialize javascript things here
        }
        document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", (evt)=>{
            initJS();
        });
        document.addEventListener("fx:after", (evt)=>{
            if (evt.target.hasAttribute("ext-fx-push")){
                history.replaceState({fixi:true, url:location.href}, "", location.href)
                history.pushState({fixi:true, url:evt.detail.cfg.response.url}, "", evt.detail.cfg.response.url)
            }
        })
        window.addEventListener("popstate", async(evt)=>{
            if (evt.state.fixi){
                let historyResp = await fetch(evt.state.url)
                document.documentElement.innerHTML = await historyResp.text()
                document.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("fx:process"))
                initJS()
            }
        })

</div>

This adds an event listener for the `fx:after` event, and if the element has the `ext-fx-push` attribute it uses the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/History_API" rel="nofollow">JavaScript History API</a> to update the URL in the browser.

Note that, like with htmx, this mechanism expects that remote systems will return full pages when the given URL is requested, so that things like refresh will work properly. Note also that scripts in head tags that are swapped in by fixi are *not* executed by default, which is the browser standard for whatever reason.

With this extension, you can write code like this:

<div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="&lt;a href=&quot;/example.html&quot;
   fx-action=&quot;/example.html&quot;
   fx-target=&quot;html&quot;&gt;
    Example Fixi-Powered Link
&lt;/a&gt;">

    <a href="/example.html"
       fx-action="/example.html"
       fx-target="html">
        Example Fixi-Powered Link
    </a>

</div>

And fixi will handle the click on this link, and the URL of the site will properly update, assuming JavaScript is enabled.

More sophisticated History handling (in particular, `head` tag handling) is left as an exercise for the reader.

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto">

<a href="#-memento-mori" id="user-content--memento-mori" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: 💀 Memento Mori"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="octicon octicon-link" /></a>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" snippet-clipboard-copy-content="/**
* Adding a single line to this file requires great internal reflection
* and thought.  You must ask yourself if your one line addition is so
* important, so critical to the success of the company, that it warrants
* a slowdown for every user on every page load.  Adding a single letter
* here could cost thousands of man hours around the world.
* 
* That is all.
*/">
